original.title: Book I: What is Justice?
original.preview: Polemarchus: I perceive, Socrates, that you and our companion are already on your way to the city.

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: I perceive, Socrates, that you and our companion are already on your way to the city.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You are not far wrong.

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: But do you see how many we are? And are you stronger than all these? For if not, you will have to remain where you are.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: May there not be the alternative that we may persuade you to let us go?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: But can you persuade us, if we refuse to listen to you?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly not.

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Then we are not going to listen; of that you may be assured.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Has no one told you of the torch-race on horseback in honour of the goddess which will take place in the evening?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: With horses! That is a novelty. Will horsemen carry torches and pass them one to another during the race?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Yes, and not only so, but a festival will be celebrated at night, which you certainly ought to see. Let us rise soon after supper and see this festival; there will be a gathering of young men, and we will have a good talk. Stay then, and do not be perverse.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I suppose, since you insist, that we must.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Very good.

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: You don't come to see me, Socrates, as often as you ought: If I were still able to go and see you I would not ask you to come to me. But at my age I can hardly get to the city, and therefore you should come oftener to the Piraeus.

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: For let me tell you, that the more the pleasures of the body fade away, the greater to me is the pleasure and charm of conversation. Do not then deny my request, but make our house your resort and keep company with these young men; we are old friends, and you will be quite at home with us.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There is nothing which for my part I like better, Cephalus, than conversing with aged men; for I regard them as travellers who have gone a journey which I too may have to go, and of whom I ought to enquire, whether the way is smooth and easy, or rugged and difficult.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And this is a question which I should like to ask of you who have arrived at that time which the poets call the 'threshold of old age'—Is life harder towards the end, or what report do you give of it?

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: I will tell you, Socrates, what my own feeling is. Men of my age flock together; we are birds of a feather, as the old proverb says; and at our meetings the tale of my acquaintance commonly is—I cannot eat, I cannot drink; the pleasures of youth and love are fled away: there was a good time once, but now that is gone, and life is no longer life.

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: Some complain of the slights which are put upon them by relations, and they will tell you sadly of how many evils their old age is the cause. But to me, Socrates, these complainers seem to blame that which is not really in fault.

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: For if old age were the cause, I too being old, and every other old man, would have felt as they do. But this is not my own experience, nor that of others whom I have known.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yes, Cephalus, but I rather suspect that people in general are not convinced by you when you speak thus; they think that old age sits lightly upon you, not because of your happy disposition, but because you are rich, and wealth is well known to be a great comforter.

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: You are right, they are not convinced: and there is something in what they say; not, however, so much as they imagine. I might answer them as Themistocles answered the Seriphian who was abusing him and saying that he was famous, not for his own merits but because he was an Athenian: 'If you had been a native of my country or I of yours, neither of us would have been famous.'

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: May I ask, Cephalus, whether your fortune was for the most part inherited or acquired by you?

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: Acquired! Socrates; do you want to know how much I acquired? In the art of making money I have been midway between my father and grandfather: for my grandfather, whose name I bear, doubled and trebled the value of his patrimony, that which he inherited being much what I possess now; but my father Lysanias reduced the property below what it is at present: and I shall be satisfied if I leave to these my sons not less but a little more than I received.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: That was why I asked you the question, because I see that you are indifferent about money, which is a characteristic rather of those who have inherited their fortunes than of those who have acquired them; the makers of fortunes have a second love of money as a creation of their own, resembling the affection of authors for their own poems, or of parents for their children, besides that natural love of it for the sake of use and profit which is common to them and all men.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What do you consider to be the greatest blessing which you have reaped from your wealth?

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: One, of which I could not expect easily to convince others. For let me tell you, Socrates, that when a man thinks himself to be near death, fears and cares enter into his mind which he never had before; the tales of a world below and the punishment which is exacted there of deeds done here were once a laughing matter to him, but now he is tormented with the thought that they may be true.

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: And the great blessing of riches, I do not say to every man, but to a good man, is, that he has had no occasion to deceive or to defraud others, either intentionally or unintentionally; and when he departs to the world below he is not in any apprehension about offerings due to the gods or debts which he owes to men.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Well said, Cephalus, but as concerning justice, what is it?—to speak the truth and to pay your debts—no more than this? And even to this are there not exceptions?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Suppose that a friend when in his right mind has deposited arms with me and he asks for them when he is not in his right mind, ought I to give them back to him? No one would say that I ought or that I should be right in doing so, any more than they would say that I ought always to speak the truth to one who is in his condition.

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: You are quite right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But then, speaking the truth and paying your debts is not a correct definition of justice.

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Quite correct, Socrates, if Simonides is to be believed.

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: I fear that I must go now, for I have to look after the sacrifices, and I hand over the argument to Polemarchus and the company.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Is not Polemarchus your heir?

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: To be sure.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Tell me then, O thou heir of the argument, what did Simonides say, and according to you truly say, about justice?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: He said that the repayment of a debt is just, and in saying so he appears to me to be right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I should be sorry to doubt the word of such a wise and inspired man, but his meaning, though probably clear to you, is the reverse of clear to me. For he certainly does not mean, as we were now saying that I ought to return a deposit of arms or of anything else to one who asks for it when he is not in his right senses; and yet a deposit cannot be denied to be a debt.

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then when the person who asks me is not in his right mind I am by no means to make the return?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Certainly not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When Simonides said that the repayment of a debt was justice, he did not mean to include that case?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Certainly not; for he thinks that a friend ought always to do good to a friend and never evil.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You mean that the return of a deposit of gold which is to the injury of the receiver, if the two parties are friends, is not the repayment of a debt—that is what you would imagine him to say?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And are enemies also to receive what we owe to them?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: To be sure, they are to receive what we owe them, and an enemy, as I take it, owes to an enemy that which is due or proper to him—that is to say, evil.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Simonides, then, after the manner of poets, would seem to have spoken darkly of the nature of justice; for he really meant to say that justice is the giving to each man what is proper to him, and this he termed a debt.

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: That must have been his meaning.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: By heaven! And if we asked him what due or proper thing is given by medicine, and to whom, what answer do you think that he would make to us?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: He would surely reply that medicine gives drugs and meat and drink to human bodies.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And what due or proper thing is given by cookery, and to what?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Seasoning to food.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And what is that which justice gives, and to whom?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: If, Socrates, we are to be guided at all by the analogy of the preceding instances, then justice is the art which gives good to friends and evil to enemies.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: That is his meaning then?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: I think so.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And who is best able to do good to his friends and evil to his enemies in time of sickness?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: The physician.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Or when they are on a voyage, amid the perils of the sea?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: The pilot.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And in what sort of actions or with a view to what result is the just man most able to do harm to his enemy and good to his friends?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: In going to war against the one and in making alliances with the other.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But when a man is well, my dear Polemarchus, there is no need of a physician?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: No.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And he who is not on a voyage has no need of a pilot?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: No.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then in time of peace justice will be of no use?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: I am very far from thinking so.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You think that justice may be of use in peace as well as in war?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Like husbandry for the acquisition of corn?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Or like shoemaking for the acquisition of shoes—that is what you mean?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And what similar use or power of acquisition has justice in time of peace?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: In contracts, Socrates, justice is of use.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And by contracts you mean partnerships?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Exactly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But is the just man or the skilful player a more useful and better partner at a game of draughts?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: The skilful player.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And in the laying of bricks and stones is the just man a more useful or better partner than the builder?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Quite the reverse.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then in what sort of partnership is the just man a better partner than the harp-player, as in playing the harp the harp-player is certainly a better partner than the just man?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: In a money partnership.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yes, Polemarchus, but surely not in the use of money; for you do not want a just man to be your counsellor in the purchase or sale of a horse; a man who is knowing about horses would be better for that, would he not?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And when you want to buy a ship, the shipwright or the pilot would be better?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then what is that joint use of silver or gold in which the just man is to be preferred?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: When you want a deposit to be kept safely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You mean when money is not wanted, but allowed to lie?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Precisely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: That is to say, justice is useful when money is useless?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: That is the inference.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And when you want to keep a pruning-hook safe, then justice is useful to the individual and to the state; but when you want to use it, then the art of the vine-dresser?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Clearly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And when you want to keep a shield or a lyre, and not to use them, you would say that justice is useful; but when you want to use them, then the art of the soldier or of the musician?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And so of all the other things—justice is useful when they are useless, and useless when they are useful?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: That is the inference.

messages.speaker: Narrator
messages.text: Several times in the course of the discussion Thrasymachus had made an attempt to get the argument into his own hands, and had been put down by the rest of the company, who wanted to hear the end.

messages.speaker: Narrator
messages.text: But when Polemarchus and I had done speaking and there was a pause, he could no longer hold his peace; and, gathering himself up, he came at us like a wild beast, seeking to devour us.

messages.speaker: Narrator
messages.text: We were quite panic-stricken at the sight of him.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: What folly, Socrates, has taken possession of you all?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And why, sillybillies, do you knock under to one another?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I say that if you want really to know what justice is, you should not only ask but answer, and you should not seek honour to yourself from the refutation of an opponent, but have your own answer.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: For there is many a one who can ask and cannot answer.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And now I will not have you say that justice is duty or advantage or profit or gain or interest, for this sort of nonsense will not do for me; I must have clearness and accuracy.

messages.speaker: Narrator
messages.text: I was panic-stricken at his words, and could not look at him without trembling.

messages.speaker: Narrator
messages.text: Indeed I believe that if I had not fixed my eye upon him, I should have been struck dumb: but when I saw his fury rising, I looked at him first, and was therefore able to reply to him.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Thrasymachus, don't be hard upon us.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Polemarchus and I may have been guilty of a little mistake in the argument, but I can assure you that the error was not intentional.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: If we were seeking for a piece of gold, you would not imagine that we were 'knocking under to one another,' and so losing our chance of finding it.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And why, when we are seeking for justice, a thing more precious than many pieces of gold, do you say that we are weakly yielding to one another and not doing our utmost to get at the truth?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Nay, my good friend, we are most willing and anxious to do so, but the fact is that we cannot.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if so, you people who know all things should pity us and not be angry with us.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: How characteristic of Socrates! That's your ironical style!

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Did I not foresee --have I not already told you, that whatever he was asked he would refuse to answer, and try irony or any other shuffle, in order that he might avoid answering?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Listen, then, he said; I proclaim that justice is nothing else than the interest of the stronger.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And now why do you not praise me? But of course you won't.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let me first understand you, I replied. Justice, as you say, is the interest of the stronger.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What, Thrasymachus, is the meaning of this? You cannot mean to say that because Polydamas, the pancratiast, is stronger than we are, and finds the eating of beef conducive to his bodily strength, that to eat beef is therefore equally for our good who are weaker than he is, and right and just for us?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: That's abominable of you, Socrates; you take the words in the sense which is most damaging to the argument.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Not at all, my good sir, I said; I am trying to understand them; and I wish that you would be a little clearer.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Well, he said, have you never heard that forms of government differ; there are tyrannies, and there are democracies, and there are aristocracies?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yes, I know.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And the government is the ruling power in each state?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And the different forms of government make laws democratical, aristocratical, tyrannical, with a view to their several interests; and these laws, which are made by them for their own interests, are the justice which they deliver to their subjects.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And him who transgresses them they punish as a breaker of the law, and unjust.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And that is what I mean when I say that in all states there is the same principle of justice, which is the interest of the government; and as the government must be supposed to have power, the only reasonable conclusion is, that everywhere there is one principle of justice, which is the interest of the stronger.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now I understand you, I said; and whether you are right or not I will try to discover.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But let me remark, that in defining justice you have yourself used the word 'interest' which you forbade me to use. It is true, however, that in your definition the words 'of the stronger' are added.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: A small addition, you must allow, he said.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Great or small, never mind about that: we must first enquire whether what you are saying is the truth.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now we are both agreed that justice is interest of some sort, but you go on to say 'of the stronger'; about this addition I am not so sure, and must therefore consider further.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Because you fancy that the shepherd or neatherd fattens of tends the sheep or oxen with a view to their own good and not to the good of himself or his master.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And you further imagine that the rulers of states, if they are true rulers, never think of their subjects as sheep, and that they are not studying their own advantage day and night.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Oh, no; and so entirely astray are you in your ideas about the just and unjust as not even to know that justice and the just are in reality another's good.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: That is to say, the interest of the ruler and stronger, and the loss of the subject and servant; and injustice the opposite.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: For the unjust is lord over the truly simple and just: he is the stronger, and his subjects do what is for his interest, and minister to his happiness, which is very far from being their own.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Consider further, most foolish Socrates, that the just is always a loser in comparison with the unjust.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: First of all, in private contracts: wherever the unjust is the partner of the just you will find that, when the partnership is dissolved, the unjust man has always more and the just less.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Secondly, in their dealings with the State: when there is an income tax, the just man will pay more and the unjust less on the same amount of income.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And when there is anything to be received the one gains nothing and the other much.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Observe also what happens when they take an office; there is the just man neglecting his affairs and perhaps suffering other losses, and getting nothing out of the public, because he is just.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Moreover he is hated by his friends and acquaintance for refusing to serve them in unlawful ways.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: But all this is reversed in the case of the unjust man.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I am speaking, as before, of injustice on a large scale in which the advantage of the unjust is more apparent.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And my meaning will be most clearly seen if we turn to that highest form of injustice in which the criminal is the happiest of men, and the sufferers or those who refuse to do injustice are the most miserable.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: That is to say tyranny, which by fraud and force takes away the property of others, not little by little but wholesale.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Comprehending in one, things sacred as well as profane, private and public; for which acts of wrong, if he were detected perpetrating any one of them singly, he would be punished and incur great disgrace.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: They who do such wrong in particular cases are called robbers of temples, and man-stealers and burglars and swindlers and thieves.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: But when a man besides taking away the money of the citizens has made slaves of them, then, instead of these names of reproach, he is termed happy and blessed, not only by the citizens but by all who hear of his having achieved the consummation of injustice.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: For mankind censure injustice, fearing that they may be the victims of it and not because they shrink from committing it.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And thus, as I have shown, Socrates, injustice, when on a sufficient scale, has more strength and freedom and mastery than justice.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And, as I said at first, justice is the interest of the stronger, whereas injustice is a man's own profit and interest.

messages.speaker: Narrator
messages.text: Thrasymachus, when he had thus spoken, having like a bathman deluged our ears with his words, had a mind to go away. But the company would not let him; they insisted that he should remain and defend his position.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Thrasymachus, excellent man, how suggestive are your remarks! And are you going to run away before you have fairly taught or learned whether they are true or not?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Is the attempt to determine the way of man's life so small a matter in your eyes—to determine how life may be passed by each one of us to the greatest advantage?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And do I differ from you as to the importance of the enquiry?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You appear rather to have no care or thought about us, Thrasymachus—whether we live better or worse from not knowing what you say you know, is to you a matter of indifference.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: For my own part I openly declare that I am not convinced, and that I do not believe injustice to be more gainful than justice, even if uncontrolled and allowed to have free play.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And how am I to convince you if you are not already convinced by what I have just said? Would you have me put the proof bodily into your souls?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Heaven forbid! I would only ask you to be consistent; or, if you change, change openly and let there be no deception.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: For I must remark, Thrasymachus, that although you began by defining the true physician in an exact sense, you did not observe a like exactness when speaking of the shepherd.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You thought that the shepherd as a shepherd tends the sheep not with a view to their own good, but like a mere diner with a view to the pleasures of the table; or as a trader for sale in the market, and not as a shepherd.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yet surely the art of the shepherd is concerned only with the good of his subjects; he has only to provide the best for them, since the perfection of the art is already ensured whenever all the requirements of it are satisfied.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And that was what I was saying just now about the ruler. I conceived that the art of the ruler, considered as ruler, whether in a state or in private life, could only regard the good of his flock or subjects.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Think! Nay, I am sure of it.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then why in the case of lesser offices do men never take them willingly without payment, unless under the idea that they govern for the advantage not of themselves but of others?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let me ask you a question: Are not the several arts different, by reason of their each having a separate function?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes, that is the difference.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And each art gives us a particular good and not merely a general one—medicine, for example, gives us health; navigation, safety at sea, and so on?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the art of payment has the special function of giving pay: but we do not confuse this with other arts, any more than the art of the pilot is to be confused with the art of medicine, because the health of the pilot may be improved by a sea voyage.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You would not be inclined to say that navigation is the art of medicine, would you?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Certainly not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Or because a man is in good health when he receives pay you would not say that the art of payment is medicine?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I should say not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Nor would you say that medicine is the art of receiving pay because a man takes fees when he is engaged in healing?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Certainly not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And we have admitted that the good of each art is specially confined to the art?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then, if there be any good which all artists have in common, that is to be attributed to something of which they all have the common use?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And when the artist is benefited by receiving pay the advantage is gained by an additional use of the art of pay, which is not the art professed by him?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: He gave a reluctant assent to this.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then the pay is not derived by the several artists from their respective arts. The truth is, that while the art of medicine gives health, and the art of the builder builds a house, another art attends them which is the art of pay.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The various arts may be doing their own business and benefiting that over which they preside, but would the artist receive any benefit from his art unless he were paid as well?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I suppose not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But does he therefore confer no benefit when he works for nothing?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Certainly, he confers a benefit.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then now, Thrasymachus, there is no longer any doubt that neither arts nor governments provide for their own interests; but, as we were before saying, they rule and provide for the interests of their subjects who are the weaker and not the stronger—to their good they attend and not to the good of the superior.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And this is the reason, my dear Thrasymachus, why no one is willing to govern; because no one likes to take in hand the reformation of evils which are not his concern without remuneration.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: For, in the execution of his work, and in giving his orders to another, the true artist does not regard his own interest, but always that of his subjects.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And therefore in order that rulers may be willing to rule, they must be paid in one of three modes of payment: money, or honour, or a penalty for refusing.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What do you mean, Socrates? The first two modes of payment are intelligible enough, but what the penalty is I do not understand, or how a penalty can be a payment.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You mean that you do not understand the nature of this payment which to the best men is the great inducement to rule? Of course you know that ambition and avarice are held to be, as indeed they are, a disgrace?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And for this reason, money and honour have no attraction for them; good men do not wish to be openly demanding payment for governing and so to get the name of hirelings, nor by secretly helping themselves out of the public revenues to get the name of thieves.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And not being ambitious they do not care about honour. Wherefore necessity must be laid upon them, and they must be induced to serve from the fear of punishment.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And this, as I imagine, is the reason why the forwardness to take office, instead of waiting to be compelled, has been deemed dishonourable.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now the worst part of the punishment is that he who refuses to rule is liable to be ruled by one who is worse than himself.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the fear of this, I conceive, induces the good to take office, not because they would, but because they cannot help—not under the idea that they are going to have any benefit or enjoyment themselves, but as a necessity.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: For there is reason to think that if a city were composed entirely of good men, then to avoid office would be as much an object of contention as to obtain office is at present.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then we should have plain proof that the true ruler is not meant by nature to regard his own interest, but that of his subjects.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So far am I from agreeing with Thrasymachus that justice is the interest of the stronger. This latter question need not be further discussed at present.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But when Thrasymachus says that the life of the unjust is more advantageous than that of the just, his new statement appears to me to be of a far more serious character.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Which of us has spoken truly? And which sort of life, Glaucon, do you prefer?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I for my part deem the life of the just to be the more advantageous.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Did you hear all the advantages of the unjust which Thrasymachus was rehearsing?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, I heard him, but he has not convinced me.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then shall we try to find some way of convincing him, if we can, that he is saying what is not true?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Most certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Well, then, Thrasymachus, suppose you begin at the beginning and answer me. You say that perfect injustice is more gainful than perfect justice?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes, that is what I say, and I have given you my reasons.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And what is your view about them? Would you call one of them virtue and the other vice?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I suppose that you would call justice virtue and injustice vice?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: What a charming notion! So likely too, seeing that I affirm injustice to be profitable and justice not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What else then would you say?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: The opposite.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And would you call justice vice?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: No, I would rather say sublime simplicity.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then would you call injustice malignity?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: No; I would rather say discretion.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And do the unjust appear to you to be wise and good?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes, at any rate those of them who are able to be perfectly unjust, and who have the power of subduing states and nations; but perhaps you imagine me to be talking of cutpurses.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I do not think that I misapprehend your meaning, Thrasymachus, but still I cannot hear without amazement that you class injustice with wisdom and virtue, and justice with the opposite.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Certainly I do so class them.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now, you are on more substantial and almost unanswerable ground; for if injustice had been admitted by you to be vice and deformity, an answer might have been given to you on received principles.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But now I perceive that you will call injustice honourable and strong, and to the unjust you will attribute all the qualities which were attributed by us before to the just, seeing that you do not hesitate to rank injustice with wisdom and virtue.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: You have guessed most infallibly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then I certainly ought not to shrink from going through with the argument so long as I have reason to think that you, Thrasymachus, are speaking your real mind.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I may be in earnest or not, but what is that to you?—to refute the argument is your business.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Very true. But will you be so good as answer yet one more question? Does the just man try to gain any advantage over the just?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Far otherwise; if he did he would not be the simple, amusing creature which he is.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And would he try to go beyond just action?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: He would not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And how would he regard the attempt to gain an advantage over the unjust; would that be considered by him as just or unjust?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: He would think it just, and would try to gain the advantage; but he would not be able.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Whether he would or would not be able is not to the point. My question is only whether the just man, while refusing to have more than another just man, would wish and claim to have more than the unjust?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes, he would.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And what of the unjust—does he claim to have more than the just man and to do more than is just?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Of course, for he claims to have more than all men.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: We may put the matter thus—the just does not desire more than his like but more than his unlike, whereas the unjust desires more than both his like and his unlike?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Nothing can be better than that statement.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the unjust is good and wise, and the just is neither?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Good again.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Very good, Thrasymachus. Now to take the case of the arts: you would admit that one man is a musician and another not a musician?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And which is wise and which is foolish?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Clearly the musician is wise, and he who is not a musician is foolish.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And he is good in as far as he is wise, and bad in as far as he is foolish?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And do you think, my excellent friend, that a musician when he adjusts the lyre would desire or claim to exceed or go beyond a musician in the tightening and loosening of the strings?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I do not think that he would.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But he would claim to exceed the non-musician?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Of course.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And what would you say of the physician? In prescribing meats and drinks would he wish to go beyond another physician or beyond the practice of medicine?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: He would not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But he would wish to go beyond the non-physician?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And about knowledge and ignorance in general: see whether you think that any man who has knowledge ever would wish to have the choice of saying or doing more than another man who has knowledge. Would he not rather say or do the same as his like in the same case?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: That, I suppose, can hardly be denied.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And what of the ignorant? Would he not desire to have more than either the knowing or the ignorant?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I dare say.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the knowing is wise?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the wise is good?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then the wise and good will not desire to gain more than his like, but more than his unlike and opposite?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I suppose so.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Whereas the bad and ignorant will desire to gain more than both?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But did we not say, Thrasymachus, that the unjust goes beyond both his like and unlike? Were not these your words?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: They were.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And you also said that the just will not go beyond his like but his unlike?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then the just is like the wise and good, and the unjust like the evil and ignorant?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: That is the inference.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And each of them is such as his like is?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: That was admitted.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then the just has turned out to be wise and good and the unjust evil and ignorant.

messages.speaker: Narrator
messages.text: Thrasymachus made all these admissions, not fluently, but with extreme reluctance; it was a hot summer's day, and the perspiration poured from him in torrents; and then I saw what I had never seen before—Thrasymachus blushing.

messages.speaker: Narrator
messages.text: As we were now agreed that justice was virtue and wisdom, and injustice vice and ignorance, Socrates proceeded to another point.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Well, Thrasymachus, that matter is now settled; but were we not also saying that injustice had strength? Do you remember?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes, I remember, but do not suppose that I approve of what you are saying or have no answer. If however I were to answer, you would be quite certain to accuse me of haranguing.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I will proceed by asking a question. Would you have the goodness to inform me, whether you think that a state, or an army, or a band of robbers and thieves, or any other gang of evil-doers could act at all if they injured one another?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: No indeed, they could not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But if they abstained from injuring one another, then they might act together better?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And this is because injustice creates divisions and hatreds and fighting, and justice imparts harmony and friendship; is not that true, Thrasymachus?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I agree, because I do not wish to quarrel with you.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: How good of you. But I should like to know also whether injustice, having this tendency to arouse hatred, wherever existing, among slaves or among freemen, will not make them hate one another and set them at variance and render them incapable of common action?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And even if injustice be found in two only, will they not quarrel and fight, and become enemies to one another and to the just?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: They will.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And suppose injustice abiding in a single person, would your wisdom say that she loses or that she retains her natural power?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Let us assume that she retains her power.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yet is not the power which injustice exercises of such a nature that wherever she takes up her abode, whether in a city, in an army, in a family, or in any other body, that body is rendered incapable of united action by reason of sedition and distraction?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And does it not become its own enemy and at variance with all that opposes it, and with the just? Is not this the case?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes, certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And is not injustice equally fatal when existing in a single person; rendering him incapable of action because he is not at unity with himself, and making him an enemy to himself and the just?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And O my friend, surely the gods are just?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Granted that they are.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But if so, the unjust will be the enemy of the gods, and the just will be their friend?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Feast away in triumph, and take your fill of the argument; I will not oppose you, lest I should displease the company.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Well then, proceed with your answers. For we have already shown that the just are clearly wiser and better and abler than the unjust, and that the unjust are incapable of common action.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: To speak of men who are evil acting vigorously together is not strictly true, for if they had been perfectly evil, they would have laid hands upon one another.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But it is evident that there must have been some remnant of justice in them, which enabled them to combine; if there had not been they would have injured one another as well as their victims.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They were but half-villains in their enterprises; for had they been whole villains, and utterly unjust, they would have been utterly incapable of action.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But whether the just have a better and happier life than the unjust is a further question which we also proposed to consider. I think that they have; but still I should like to examine further, for no light matter is at stake, nothing less than the rule of human life.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Proceed.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I will proceed by asking a question: Would you not say that a horse has some end?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I should.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the end or use of a horse or of anything would be that which could not be accomplished, or not so well accomplished, by any other thing?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I do not understand.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let me explain: Can you see, except with the eye?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Certainly not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Or hear, except with the ear?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: No.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: These then may be truly said to be the ends of these organs?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: They may.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But you can cut off a vine-branch with a dagger or with a chisel, and in many other ways?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Of course.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And yet not so well as with a pruning-hook made for the purpose?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: May we not say that this is the end of a pruning-hook?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: We may.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then now I think you will have no difficulty in understanding my meaning when I asked whether the end of anything would be that which could not be accomplished, or not so well accomplished, by any other thing?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I understand your meaning, and assent.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And that to which an end is appointed has also an excellence? Need I ask again whether the eye has an end?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: It has.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And has not the eye an excellence?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the ear has an end and an excellence also?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the same is true of all other things; they have each of them an end and a special excellence?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: That is so.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Well, and can the eyes fulfil their end if they are wanting in their own proper excellence and have a defect instead?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: How can they, if they are blind and cannot see?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I would rather ask the question more generally: whether the things which fulfil their ends fulfil them by their own proper excellence, and fail of fulfilling them by their own defect?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And has not the soul an end which nothing else can fulfil? For example, to superintend and command and deliberate and the like. Are not these functions proper to the soul, and can they rightly be assigned to any other?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: To no other.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And is not life to be reckoned among the ends of the soul?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Assuredly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And has not the soul an excellence also?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And can she or can she not fulfil her own ends when deprived of that excellence?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: She cannot.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then an evil soul must necessarily be an evil ruler and superintendent, and the good soul a good ruler?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes, necessarily.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And we have admitted that justice is the excellence of the soul, and injustice the defect of the soul?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: That has been admitted.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then the just soul and the just man will live well, and the unjust man will live ill?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: That is what your argument proves.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And he who lives well is blessed and happy, and he who lives ill the reverse of happy?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then the just is happy, and the unjust miserable?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: So be it.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But happiness and not misery is profitable.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Of course.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then, my blessed Thrasymachus, injustice can never be more profitable than justice.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Let this, Socrates, be your entertainment at the Bendidea.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: For which I am indebted to you, now that you have grown gentle towards me and have left off scolding.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Nevertheless, I have not been well entertained; but that was my own fault and not yours. As an epicure snatches a taste of every dish which is successively brought to table, not having allowed himself time to enjoy the one before, so have I gone from one subject to another without having discovered what I sought at first—the nature of justice.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I left that enquiry and turned away to consider whether justice is virtue and wisdom or evil and folly; and when there arose a further question about the comparative advantages of justice and injustice, I could not refrain from passing on to that.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the result of the whole discussion has been that I know nothing at all. For I know not what justice is, and therefore I am not likely to know whether it is or is not a virtue, nor can I say whether the just man is happy or unhappy.

modern.title: Book I: What Even Is Justice?
modern.preview: Polemarchus: Yo Socrates, I see you and your friend are trying to head back to the city.

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Yo Socrates, I see you and your friend are trying to head back to the city.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You're not wrong.

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: But look how many of us there are! You think you can take all of us? If not, you're staying put.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What if we just... talked you into letting us go?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: How are you gonna convince us if we're not even listening?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Fair point.

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Then we're definitely not listening. That's final.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Has anyone told you about the torch relay race on horseback tonight? It's for the goddess.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: On horses?! That's new. So riders will pass torches to each other during the race?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Yeah, and there's going to be this whole festival at night that you need to see. We'll eat dinner and then go check it out. There'll be tons of young people there and we can have some good conversations. Come on, don't be difficult.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I guess since you're insisting, we have to stay.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Alright then.

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: Socrates, you don't visit me nearly enough! If I could still make it to the city easily, I wouldn't be asking you to come out here. But at my age, it's hard for me to get around, so you should come to the port more often.

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: Here's the thing - as physical pleasures fade away, I find myself enjoying conversation more and more. So please don't say no, make yourself at home here with these young guys. We're old friends, you'll be totally comfortable with us.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Honestly, there's nothing I like more than talking with older people. I think of you guys as travelers who've been down a road I might have to take someday. I want to know - is it smooth sailing or is it rough?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So I'd love to ask you this, since you're at what poets call the 'threshold of old age' - is life harder toward the end, or what's your take on it?

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: I'll tell you how I see it. People my age hang out together - birds of a feather, you know? And when we get together, everyone's complaining: 'I can't eat, I can't drink, the good times are over, life sucks now.'

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: Some people blame their families for treating them badly and go on about how terrible old age is. But I think they're blaming the wrong thing.

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: If old age was really the problem, then I'd be miserable too, and so would every other old person. But that's not my experience, and it's not what I've seen with others either.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Okay Cephalus, but I think most people aren't buying what you're selling. They think old age is easy for you not because you're chill, but because you're rich. Everyone knows money makes things easier.

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: You're right, they don't buy it. And there's some truth to what they're saying, just not as much as they think. It's like what Themistocles said to that guy who was talking trash - fame depends on circumstances, not just personal merit.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Can I ask - did you inherit your money or make it yourself?

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: Made it! Want to know how much? I'm basically the middle ground between my grandfather and father when it comes to money. My grandfather doubled or tripled what he inherited. But my dad blew through most of it. I'll be happy if I can leave my sons at least what I got, maybe a little more.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: That's why I asked - I noticed you don't seem that attached to money. That's usually more of a thing with people who inherited it rather than earned it. People who build wealth love it like artists love their work, plus they love it for what it can do.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So what's the biggest benefit you've gotten from being wealthy?

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: Something most people probably wouldn't believe. Here's the thing - when someone thinks they're about to die, they start worrying about stuff they never cared about before. All those stories about the afterlife and punishment? They used to be funny, but now they're terrifying.

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: The great thing about being rich - at least for a good person - is that you never had to screw anyone over. So when you die, you're not stressed about owing money to people or the gods.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Well said, Cephalus. But about justice - is it really just 'tell the truth and pay your debts'? That's it? Even that has exceptions, right?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Like, what if a friend gave you their weapons when they were sane, but then they went crazy and asked for them back? You wouldn't give them back, right? And you probably wouldn't be totally honest with someone who's lost their mind either.

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: You're absolutely right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So 'tell the truth and pay your debts' isn't really a complete definition of justice.

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Actually, Socrates, that's totally right - if we're going with what Simonides said.

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: Sorry, I gotta go handle the religious stuff. I'm passing this argument off to Polemarchus and everyone else.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Isn't Polemarchus your heir anyway?

messages.speaker: Cephalus
messages.text: Absolutely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Alright, heir to the argument, what did Simonides actually say about justice? You seem to think he was right.

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: He said paying back what you owe is justice, and I think he's onto something.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Look, I don't want to doubt such a wise guy, but I'm not getting his meaning. He obviously doesn't mean what we just talked about - that you should return weapons to someone who's mentally unstable, even though technically that's a debt.

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So when someone's not in their right mind, I shouldn't give them back their stuff?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Definitely not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So Simonides didn't mean that case when he said paying debts is justice?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Of course not. He thinks friends should always help friends and never harm them.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So you're saying that returning money that would hurt the person getting it back, if they're your friend, isn't really paying a debt - that's what you think he meant?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Exactly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What about enemies? Should they get what we owe them too?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: For sure, they should get what we owe them. And what we owe an enemy is what they deserve - which is basically harm.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So Simonides was being all poetic and mysterious about justice. He really meant that justice is giving everyone what they deserve, and he called that a 'debt.'

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: That must be what he meant.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Okay! So if we asked him what medicine gives people and who it gives it to, what would he say?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: He'd say medicine gives drugs, food, and drinks to bodies.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And what does cooking give, and to what?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Seasoning to food.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And what does justice give, and to whom?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: If we're following the same pattern, then justice gives good stuff to friends and bad stuff to enemies.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So that's what he meant?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: I think so.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And who's best at helping friends and hurting enemies when they're sick?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: A doctor.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Or when they're on a dangerous boat trip?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: A ship captain.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So when would a just person be the best at helping friends and hurting enemies?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: In war - fighting against enemies and teaming up with friends.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But when someone's healthy, they don't need a doctor, right?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Nope.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And when they're not on a ship, they don't need a captain?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So during peacetime, justice is useless?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: I definitely don't think that.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You think justice is useful in peace AND war?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Yeah.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Like farming is useful for getting grain?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Yeah.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Or shoemaking is useful for getting shoes - that's what you mean?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Exactly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So what's justice useful for getting during peacetime?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: For contracts and deals, Socrates.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: By contracts you mean partnerships?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Exactly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But for playing checkers, would you rather partner with a just person or someone who's actually good at checkers?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: The person who's good at checkers.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And for construction work, would you rather have a just person or an actual builder as your partner?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Definitely the builder.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So what kind of partnership would you prefer a just person over a musician, the way you'd prefer a musician over a just person for music?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Money partnerships.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Sure, but not for actually using money, right? Like, you wouldn't want a just person helping you buy or sell a horse - you'd want someone who knows about horses, wouldn't you?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Totally.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And for buying a ship, you'd want a shipbuilder or captain, right?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So when would you prefer a just person for handling money?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: When you want to keep it safe.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You mean when you're not using it, just storing it?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Exactly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So justice is useful when money is useless?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: That's what it sounds like.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And when you want to keep garden shears safe, justice is useful for individuals and society, but when you want to use them, you need a gardener?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Obviously.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And when you want to store a shield or guitar safely, justice is useful, but when you want to use them, you need a soldier or musician?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: Definitely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So with everything else - justice is useful when things are useless, and useless when things are useful?

messages.speaker: Polemarchus
messages.text: That seems to be the logic.

messages.speaker: Narrator
messages.text: Thrasymachus had been trying to jump into this conversation multiple times, but everyone kept shutting him down because they wanted to hear how it ended.

messages.speaker: Narrator
messages.text: But when Polemarchus and I finished talking and there was a pause, he couldn't stay quiet anymore. He gathered himself up and came at us like a wild animal ready to attack.

messages.speaker: Narrator
messages.text: We were totally freaked out by the sight of him.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: What is wrong with you people, Socrates?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And why are you idiots just going easy on each other?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Look, if you actually want to know what justice is, you need to do more than just ask questions - you need to give answers. Stop trying to look smart by tearing down other people's arguments and come up with your own.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Plenty of people can ask questions but can't answer them.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And don't give me any of that BS about justice being duty or advantage or profit or whatever. That kind of nonsense won't work on me - I need clear, precise answers.

messages.speaker: Narrator
messages.text: I was terrified by what he said and couldn't even look at him without shaking.

messages.speaker: Narrator
messages.text: Honestly, I think if I hadn't looked at him first, I would've been speechless. But since I saw him getting angry, I looked at him early and was able to respond.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Thrasymachus, don't be so hard on us.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Maybe Polemarchus and I made some mistakes in our reasoning, but I promise it wasn't on purpose.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: If we were looking for actual gold, you wouldn't think we were 'going easy on each other' and missing our chance to find it.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So why, when we're searching for justice - something way more valuable than gold - do you think we're being weak and not trying our hardest to find the truth?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Come on, we really want to figure this out, but the truth is we just can't.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So maybe you smart people should feel sorry for us instead of getting angry.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: That's so typical Socrates! There's that ironic style of yours!

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Didn't I predict this? Haven't I already told you that whatever you ask him, he'll refuse to answer and use irony or some other trick to avoid giving a real response?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Fine, listen up. Justice is nothing more than the interest of the stronger.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Now why aren't you praising me? Oh right, of course you won't.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let me make sure I understand you first. You're saying justice is the interest of the stronger.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But what do you mean by that? You can't be saying that because some athlete is stronger than us and beef helps him stay strong, that eating beef is therefore good and just for us weaker people too?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: That's terrible, Socrates! You're twisting my words in the worst possible way.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Not at all, I'm just trying to understand. I wish you'd be clearer about what you mean.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Look, haven't you heard that governments are different? There are dictatorships, democracies, aristocracies?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yeah, I know that.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And the government is whoever has the power in each place?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Obviously.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And different governments make laws that benefit themselves - democratic laws, aristocratic laws, dictatorial laws. These laws, made for their own benefit, are what they call 'justice' for their subjects.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And anyone who breaks these laws gets punished as a lawbreaker and 'unjust' person.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: That's what I mean - in every society, justice follows the same principle: it's what benefits the government. And since the government has the power, the logical conclusion is that justice everywhere is just what benefits the stronger.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Okay, now I get what you're saying. Whether you're right or wrong, I'll try to figure out.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But let me point out that you just used the word 'interest' in your definition, which you told me I couldn't use. Though I guess you added 'of the stronger' to it.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: It's a small addition, you have to admit.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Big or small, whatever - first we need to figure out if what you're saying is actually true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: We both agree that justice is some kind of interest, but you're adding 'of the stronger.' I'm not sure about that part and need to think about it more.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: You think shepherds feed and care for sheep because it's good for the sheep, not because it benefits themselves or their boss.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And you also think that real rulers never see their people as sheep and aren't constantly thinking about their own advantage.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: You're so clueless about justice and injustice that you don't even realize that justice is really just doing what's good for someone else.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Specifically, what's good for the ruler and stronger person, while being bad for the subject and weaker person. Injustice is the opposite.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: The unjust person rules over honest, just people. He's stronger, and his subjects do what benefits him, making him happy while they suffer.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Think about it more, Socrates - you're being naive. Just people always lose compared to unjust ones.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: First, in business deals: when an honest person partners with a dishonest one, the dishonest person always ends up with more money when they split up.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Second, with taxes: an honest person pays more and a dishonest person pays less on the same income.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And when there's government money to be made, the honest person gets nothing while the other person gets a lot.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Look at what happens in politics too - the honest person neglects his own business, maybe loses money, and gets nothing from public service because he's honest.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Plus his friends and family hate him for refusing to help them do shady stuff.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: But it's completely the opposite for the unjust person.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I'm talking about injustice on a massive scale, where the benefits for unjust people are really obvious.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: You'll see this most clearly if you look at the ultimate form of injustice - where the criminal is the happiest person alive, while the victims or people who refuse to be unjust are completely miserable.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I'm talking about tyranny - using fraud and force to steal everyone else's stuff, not bit by bit but all at once.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Taking everything - sacred and secular, private and public. If someone got caught doing any one of these things individually, they'd be punished and totally disgraced.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: When people do these individual crimes, we call them temple robbers, kidnappers, burglars, con artists, thieves.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: But when someone steals citizens' money AND enslaves them, instead of being insulted, they're called happy and blessed - not just by their own people but by everyone who hears about their 'perfect injustice.'

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: People condemn injustice because they're afraid of being victims, not because they wouldn't do it themselves.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: So like I said, Socrates, injustice on a big enough scale is stronger, freer, and more powerful than justice.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And like I said from the start, justice is what benefits the stronger, while injustice benefits yourself.

messages.speaker: Narrator
messages.text: After that speech, Thrasymachus tried to leave like he'd just dropped a mic. But everyone made him stay and defend his position.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Thrasymachus! Are you seriously about to leave before we figure out if what you said is even true?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Is figuring out how to live the best life really that unimportant to you?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Do you think I don't care about what's important?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: It kind of seems like you don't care whether we live well or not, since you won't share what you claim to know.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: For what it's worth, I'm not convinced. I don't believe injustice is better than justice, even when you can get away with it completely.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: How am I supposed to convince you if everything I just said didn't work? Want me to physically implant the proof into your brain?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Please no! I just want you to be consistent. Or if you're going to change your position, do it openly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Here's the thing, Thrasymachus—you were being precise when you defined a true physician, but you weren't as careful when talking about shepherds.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You said shepherds care for sheep like someone sizing up their dinner—not like a real shepherd who actually looks after the flock's wellbeing.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But a true shepherd's whole job is to provide the best for the sheep. That's literally what makes someone good at shepherding.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Same with rulers. The art of ruling, when done right, is about looking after the people being ruled—not yourself.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Think that? I'm absolutely sure of it.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then why doesn't anyone take smaller government jobs unless they're getting paid? Isn't it because they know they're serving others, not themselves?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Here's a question: aren't different arts defined by having different functions?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yeah, that's what makes them different.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And each art provides a specific benefit, not a generic one. Medicine gives health, navigation gives safety at sea, and so on.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Sure.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And getting paid is its own separate art—we don't confuse it with the pilot's art just because a sea voyage might make you healthier.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You wouldn't say navigation IS medicine, would you?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Obviously not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And just because someone's healthy while getting paid doesn't make payment the same as medicine?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Of course not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And you wouldn't call medicine the 'art of getting paid' just because doctors charge fees?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Definitely not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So we agree each art has its own specific benefit?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: If there's any benefit that ALL practitioners share, it must come from something they all use in common, right?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
