messages.text: Right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So when an artist benefits from getting paid, that comes from using the art of payment—not from their actual profession?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: ...I guess so.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So the pay isn't coming from practicing medicine or building houses. The various arts do their own thing for whoever they serve—but artists only benefit personally when they get paid on top of that.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Would artists get any personal benefit from practicing their art if they weren't paid?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I suppose not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But they'd still be providing a benefit even if they worked for free, right?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yeah, they would.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So there you have it! Arts and governments don't serve their own interests—they serve the interests of the people under them, the weaker ones, not the stronger.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: That's exactly why nobody wants to govern without compensation. Nobody wants to fix problems that aren't theirs for free.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: A true professional always thinks about their clients' interests, not their own.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So rulers have to be paid in one of three ways: money, honor, or—here's the weird one—a penalty for refusing.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Wait, what do you mean, Socrates? Money and honor make sense. But how is a penalty a form of payment?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You don't get what motivates the best people to lead? Good people consider greed and ambition pretty shameful, you know.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That's true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Good people don't want to look like they're demanding money for leadership, or secretly stealing from public funds. And they don't care about the honor either since they're not ambitious.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So the only thing that makes them lead is necessity—the fear of being punished.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: That's why eagerly pursuing power instead of being reluctantly called to it has always been seen as shameful.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And here's the real penalty: if you refuse to lead, you might end up being ruled by someone worse than you.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Good people don't run for office because they want to—they do it because they HAVE to. Because if they don't, who knows what idiot will end up in charge?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Actually, imagine a city made up entirely of good people. Everyone would be fighting NOT to be in charge, the opposite of now!

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: That proves my point: true rulers aren't meant to serve themselves—they're meant to serve their people.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So no, Thrasymachus, I completely disagree that justice is the interest of the stronger.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But there's an even more important question here. You say unjust life is better than a just life. Glaucon, which do you prefer?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: The just life, obviously.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Did you hear all those 'benefits' of injustice Thrasymachus listed?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yeah, I heard him. Still not convinced though.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Should we try to prove him wrong?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Absolutely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Alright Thrasymachus, let's start fresh. You're saying complete injustice is better than complete justice?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: That's exactly what I'm saying. I already explained why.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And which would you call virtue and which vice?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Duh.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So I'm guessing you'd call justice the virtue and injustice the vice?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Haha, cute guess! I just said injustice is profitable and justice isn't. Why would injustice be the vice?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then what would you say?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: The opposite.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You're calling justice a vice?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I'd call it 'naive idealism.'

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And injustice is evil?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I'd call it 'strategic thinking.'

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So unjust people are wise and good to you?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: The ones who can be completely unjust, yeah—the ones who can conquer whole countries. Unless you think I'm just talking about petty thieves.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I get what you're saying, but I'm genuinely shocked that you put injustice in the same category as wisdom and virtue, and justice in the opposite.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: That's exactly my position.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: That's actually a harder position to argue against. If you just admitted injustice was bad, I could use conventional arguments. But you're calling injustice honorable and strong, putting it right up there with wisdom and virtue.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: You nailed it.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Well, I can't back down as long as I think you actually believe this. You do believe it, right?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Whether I believe it or not shouldn't matter to you—just prove me wrong.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Fair enough. One more question: does a just person try to get an advantage over another just person?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: No way—that's why just people are naive losers.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Would they try to outdo just ACTIONS?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Nope.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What about gaining advantage over unjust people—would that seem right to a just person?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: They'd think it's right and try to do it, but they'd fail.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: That's not the point. My question is: does a just person want to gain advantage only over unjust people, not other just people?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yeah.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And unjust people—do they try to get more than just people and do more than what's fair?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Obviously—they want more than everyone.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So the just person wants more than unlike people but not similar people, while unjust people want more than both?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Perfectly stated.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the unjust person is good and wise while the just person is neither?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yep.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Okay, new example. You'd agree some people are musicians and some aren't?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Sure.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Which is wise and which is foolish?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: The musician is wise, the non-musician is foolish.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And wise = good, foolish = bad?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yeah.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So when a musician tunes a lyre, would they try to outdo another musician in how they adjust the strings?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I don't think so.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But they would claim to know more than a non-musician?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Definitely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Same with doctors—would they try to prescribe differently than other doctors, or just differently than non-doctors?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Differently than non-doctors.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: In general, would any expert try to outdo another expert in their field? Or would they say and do the same things?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I guess they'd do the same as other experts.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And ignorant people would try to outdo everyone—experts and non-experts alike?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Probably.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the expert is wise?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And wise is good?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Sure.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So the wise and good try to outdo only unlike people, while the bad and ignorant try to outdo everyone?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I suppose.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But wait—didn't we just establish that unjust people try to outdo everyone, while just people only try to outdo unlike people?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: We did.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And didn't you say the just person only tries to outdo unlike people?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: ...Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So the just person is like the wise and good, and the unjust is like the evil and ignorant?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: That seems to follow.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And each becomes like their counterpart?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yeah, we agreed to that.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So the just person turns out to be wise and good, and the unjust person is evil and ignorant.

messages.speaker: Narrator
messages.text: Thrasymachus admitted all of this very reluctantly. It was a hot summer day and he was sweating like crazy. And then something happened that I'd never seen before—Thrasymachus blushed.

messages.speaker: Narrator
messages.text: Since we'd now agreed that justice was virtue and wisdom, while injustice was vice and ignorance, Socrates moved to another point.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Okay, we've settled that. But earlier you said injustice was powerful. Remember?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yeah, I remember. And I'm not convinced by what you said, but I know if I try to respond you'll just accuse me of giving speeches.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Here's a question: do you think a state, an army, or even a gang of criminals could function if they kept hurting each other?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: No, they couldn't.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But if they didn't hurt each other, they could work together better?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yeah.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: That's because injustice creates division and conflict, while justice creates harmony and friendship—right, Thrasymachus?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Fine, I'll agree to that to avoid more arguing.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So nice of you. But tell me—if injustice makes people hate each other wherever it appears—among slaves, free people, anyone—wouldn't it make them incapable of working together?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes, it would.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if there were just two unjust people, wouldn't they fight and become enemies?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: They would.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if injustice lived in just one person, does it lose its power or keep it?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Let's say it keeps it.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But isn't it true that wherever injustice lives—in a city, army, family, whatever—it creates internal conflict and makes that group fight against itself AND against just people?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yeah.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And wouldn't injustice in a single person do the same thing? Make them unable to act because they're at war with themselves, and make them their own enemy?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And surely the gods are just, aren't they?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Let's say they are.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then unjust people are enemies of the gods, and just people are their friends?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Enjoy your victory feast then. I won't fight you anymore—I don't want to upset everyone here.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Good. We've established that just people are wiser, better, and more capable than unjust ones, and that unjust people can't even work together properly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When we talk about 'evil people accomplishing things together,' that's not quite right. If they were truly evil, they'd have destroyed each other.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There must have been some justice in them that allowed them to cooperate. Otherwise they would have hurt each other along with their victims.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They were half-villains at best. Full villains couldn't get anything done.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But there's still the question of whether just people live better, happier lives. I think they do, but I want to look more carefully—this is literally about how to live.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Go ahead.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Would you say a horse has a function—something it can do that nothing else can do as well?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yeah.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Can you see with anything other than eyes?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: No.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Or hear with anything other than ears?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: No.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So that's their function. You could cut a vine branch with a dagger, but not as well as with pruning shears.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So the function of something is what it does best or uniquely?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: I get it now.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And things with functions also have excellence—like eyes need the excellence of good vision to function well?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yeah.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Can eyes do their job if they're blind instead of having good vision?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Obviously not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So things succeed through their proper excellence and fail through their defect?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now, doesn't the soul have a function that nothing else can perform? Like directing, commanding, deliberating—aren't these uniquely the soul's job?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And living itself—isn't that one of the soul's functions?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Definitely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the soul has its own excellence?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Can the soul do its job well without that excellence?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: No.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So a bad soul has to be a bad ruler and director, while a good soul is a good one?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Necessarily.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And didn't we agree that justice is the soul's excellence and injustice is its defect?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: We did.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So the just person will live well, and the unjust person will live badly?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: That's what your argument proves.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And living well means being happy, while living badly means being miserable?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Obviously.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So just people are happy and unjust people are miserable?

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Fine.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And being happy is beneficial while being miserable isn't.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Of course.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then, my friend Thrasymachus, injustice can NEVER be more beneficial than justice.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: There's your victory party, Socrates. Enjoy the festival.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Thanks to you for being such a good sport once you stopped yelling at me.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But honestly? I haven't really been satisfied by this discussion—that's on me, not you. I've been like someone eating too fast at a buffet, jumping from one dish to another without really enjoying any of them.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I started asking about the nature of justice, then got distracted by whether it's virtue or vice, then whether it leads to happiness—without ever answering the first question.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The result? I still don't know what justice actually is. And without knowing that, how can I know if it's a virtue, or if just people are happy? I've proven nothing after all this.
